0.text: This scene opens on a plain in Denmark. Fortinbras, Prince of Norway, marches with his army across Denmark on the way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and meets a captain who describes the small and worthless piece of land in Poland young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet reflects on the futility of war, bloodshed, and the persistent Poles, who will fight for their worthless land to the bitter end. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern walk ahead, affording Hamlet the opportunity to reflect in solitude. He contrasts his inaction to the aggressive behavior of young Fortinbras, remarking in despair, 'How all occasions do inform against me, / And spur my dull revenge. He is angry at himself for delaying his father's vengeance, especially as he watches nearly twenty thousand men bravely marching to their death for a meaningless piece of land. Hamlet resolves that from now on his 'thoughts  be bloody, or be nothing worth.

2.text: This scene begins on a plain in Denmark. Fortinbras, Prince of Norway, marches with his army through Denmark on his way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and encounters a captain who describes the small and vainglorious piece of land in Poland that young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet reflects on the futility of war, blood, and the stubborn Poles who fight to the end for their vainglorious land. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern move forward, allowing Hamlet to reflect in solitude. He compares his inaction to the aggressive conduct of young Fortinbras, noting with despair: 'How all occasions do instruct me / And teach me how to make my absence seem / To upbraid, though not to anger him; / And thus I have with swift decision made my choice / And every step that moves me is either fault / Tolerated in itself or in it placed / So pardoned as methinks it is. He is angry with himself for delaying his father's revenge, especially when he looks at nearly twenty thousand men marching bravely towards their death for a piece of land of no importance. Hamlet decides that from now on, his thoughts will be bloody, or they will be worth nothing.

4.text: The scene begins on a plain in Denmark. Fortinbras, the Prince of Norway, marches with his army through Denmark on their way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and encounters a captain who describes the small and vain piece of land in Poland that young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet ponders the futility of war, the bloodshed, and the stubborn Poles who fight to the end for their worthless land. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern move away, leaving Hamlet to reflect alone. He compares his inaction to the aggressive conduct of young Fortinbras, noting with despair: 'How all occasions do instruct me / And teach me how to make my absence seem / Most like a courtesy than a loss, though I / Am as sure as surety in the credulous / vault of your eye. So, a double deference / Takes off ten thousand dangers on me, / Tunes me to an answer. How all solicitudes / But this, and these, so seasonally / Affair with such dull patience, as, once more / Girds up the mind to fight and takes possession / O'er self. But that the last line of it, nor / The worst request of business, shall the world know, / No, let it not be seen, they found me so.' He is angry with himself for delaying his father's revenge, especially when he looks at nearly twenty thousand men marching bravely towards their deaths for a piece of land of no importance. Hamlet decides that from now on, his thoughts will be bloody, or they will have no value.

6.text:
The scene begins on a plain in Denmark. Fortinbras, the prince of Denmark, marches with his army through Denmark on their way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and meets a captain who describes the small and insignificant piece of land in Poland that the young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet ponders the futility of war, the bloodshed, and the stubborn Poles who fight to the end for their worthless land. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern move away, leaving Hamlet to reflect alone. He compares his inaction to the aggressive conduct of the young Fortinbras, noting with despair: 'How all occasions do instruct me / How all occasions do instruct me / And teach me, so, to put them in remembrance / To put them in remembrance, to make me a will others for it, / For it / And, in a nutshell, here's the sum / Of why we do this, the value of this / To be, or not to be, that is the question / Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer / The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune / Or to take arms against a sea of troubles / And by opposing end them. To die, to sleep / No more; and by a sleep to say we end / The heartache and the thousand natural shocks / That flesh is heir to. 'Tis a consummation / Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep; / To sleep, perchance to dream—ay, there's the rub / For in that sleep of death what dreams may come / When we have shuffled off this mortal coil / Must give us pause. There's the respect / That makes calamity of so long life / For who would bear the whips and scorns of time / The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely / The pangs of despis'd love, the law's delay, / The insolence of office and the spurns / That patient merit of th' unworthy takes / When he himself might his quietus make / With a bare bodkin? who would fardels bear / To grunt and sweat under a weary life, / But that the dread of something after death, / The undiscover'd country from whose bourn / No traveller returns, puzzles the will / And makes us rather bear those ills we have / Than fly to others that we know not of? / Thus conscience does make cowards of us all, / And thus the native hue of resolution / Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, / And enterprises of great pitch and moment / With this regard their currents turn awry, / And lose the name of action.'

8.text:
The scene begins in a Danish plain. Fortinbras, the prince of Denmark, marches with his army through Denmark on their way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and meets a captain who describes the small and insignificant piece of land in Poland that young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet reflects on the absurdity of war, the bloody carnage, and the obstinate Poles who fight to the end for their worthless land. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern depart, leaving Hamlet to reflect alone. He compares his inaction to the aggressive behavior of young Fortinbras, noting with despair:

'How all occasions do instruct me
So aptly and with such warm importunity!
Why, sometimes glutted with my incertain fates,
And in my state of doubt, I smile and laugh at
This place, that men call sacred and regard
With such deep reverence. But what would you
Are you sure that ever the time of year
Fell into an oath? Most holy and most
Iniquity! Most foul and most unnatural!'

10.text:
The scene begins in a Danish plain. Fortinbras, Prince of Denmark, marches with his army through Denmark en route to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and encounters a captain who describes the small and insignificant piece of land in Poland that the young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet ponders the absurdity of war, the bloody carnage, and the stubborn Poles who fight to the end for their worthless land. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern depart, leaving Hamlet to reflect alone. He compares his inaction to the aggressive conduct of the young Fortinbras, noting with despair:

'How aptly all occasions instruct me,
And with such warm insistence!
Why, sometimes, I am melancholy, full of sores,
And I go to bed more lowly and more bitterly unhappy;
But tell me, friends, why the presence of my mistress
Gives me such a lift, and why my
Affection finds rest in that most holy church,
Where malice and holy sacrifice are mingled?
Would not the world, on the contrary, turn upside down?
Oh, would not the world, in holy zeal, turn
Against the crown? Very holy and very
Iniquitous! Very ugly and very naturally
Against reason!'

13.text:
The scene begins in a Danish plain. Fortinbras, Prince of Denmark, marches with his army through Denmark on their way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and encounters a captain who describes the small and insignificant piece of land in Poland that young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet meditates on the absurdity of war, the bloody battle, and the obstinate Poles who fight to the end for their land of little value. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern depart, leaving Hamlet to reflect alone. He compares his inaction to the aggressive conduct of the young Fortinbras, noting with despair:

'How all occasions do instruct me
So ample in themselves,
A little more than kin, and less than kind,
Why was I to be the lord of this fair city, and it pleased not the crown?
Wherein I see more woes than this man
Might see, were he of my rank,
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
Th' oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of th' unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will,
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pith and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.

Choice of the best room next my chamber,
And him to put his to 't before this parliament,
For him to speak in support of his demand,

16.text:
How all occurrences
Make me pursue my vengeful studies!
What a piece of work is man!
How noble in reason!
How infinite in faculty!
In form and movement, how expressive and admirable!
In action, how like an angel!
In apprehension, how like a god!
The beauty of the world.
The perfect image of animals.
And yet, for me, what is this quintessence of dust?
Man does not please me:
Nor do I have any intellectual affection for him.
He must be in folly, for he smiles on his face, and thus begins an alliance.
Oh, if I had one to rule in this country,
To rule in this country, over which the jay reigns,
When he, who from below has sought out his brain,
I would want, under the whiteness of eternity,
To console with him, the numerous wicked stars,
Told in the superstitious geography of yesteryear,
Which have walked on the head of him, so feeble-minded.
His form confuses the eye of his disturbed reason,
For it is a heavy mass, heavy and a wooded part,
Which, when he speaks, the air, a charnel house,
Provides his ears with a groan,
As when he lies down to sleep,
The wooden fools, full of remorse then,
Bite their fingers and move away.

But softly, what shines through this window?
It is the east, and the ghost of Hamlet's father
Appears once again.

The glow of the window.
The glow of the window.

20.text:
All occurrences

Make me pursue vindictive studies!
What a masterpiece is man!
How noble he is in reason!
How infinite he is in faculty!
In form and movement, how expressive and admirable he is!
In action, how he resembles an angel!
In perception, how he resembles a god!
The beauty of the world.
The perfect image of animals.
And yet, for me, what is this quintessence of dust?
Man does not please me:
Nor do I have intellectual love for him.
He must be mad, because he smiles on his face, and thus begins an alliance.
Oh, if I had a reign over this earth,
To reign over this earth, over which the crow rules,
When it, from below, sought his brain,
I would want, under the whiteness of eternity,
To console with him, the numerous malicious stars,
Mentioned in the superstitious geography of last year,
Who marched on his head, with so little brain.
His troubled form troubles the eye of his troubled reason,
Since he is a heavy mass, heavy and a wooded part,
Which, when he speaks, the air, a vulture,
Provides his ears with a whimpering,
As when he stretches out to sleep,
The mad, full of remorse afterwards,
Bite their fingers and move away.

But gently, what shines through this window?
It is the east, and the shadow of Hamlet's father
Appears once again.

The light of the window.
The light of the window.

 It has to be mad, since he smiles on his face, and that is how he starts an alliance.
 Oh, if I had a reign over this earth,
 To reign over this earth, on which the crow reigns,
 When he, from below, searched for his brain,
 I would want, under the whiteness of eternity,
 To console with him, the numerous malevolent stars,
 Mentioned in the superstitious geography of last year,
 Who walked on his head, with so little brain.
 His troubled form troubles the eye of his troubled reason,
 Since he is a heavy mass, heavy and a wooded part,
 Which, when he speaks, the air, a vulture,
 Provides his ears to a complainant,
 As when he stretches to sleep,
 The mad, full of remorse afterwards,
 Bite their fingers and go.

 But gently, what shines through this window?
 It is the east, and the shadow of father Hamlet
 Appears once again.

 The light of the window.
 The light of the window.

50.text:
All occurrences

Make me pursue vindictive studies!
 What mastery is man!
 How noble he is by reason!
 How infinite he is in faculty!
 In form and movement, how expressive and admirable he is!
 In action, how he resembles an angel!
 To perception, how he resembles a god!
 The beauty of the world.
 The perfect image of animals.
 And yet, for me, what quintessence of dust?
 Man does not please me:
 Nor do I have an intellectual love for him.

0.text: This short scene shifts to the Volscian Senate in Corioli, depicting the Senators engaged in a council of war. They discuss the likely consequences of Romes premature discovery of their preparations for war. Aufidius is irritated by this development and reproaches the First Senator for not keeping the Volscian preparations a closely guarded secret. When the First Senator denies any knowledge of a military leak, Aufidius produces a letter that he had received four days earlier stating that the Romans have raised an army against the Volscians under the leadership of Cominius, Marcius, and Titus Lartius. The letter also states that the Roman citizens are rebelling. To dispel some of Aufidius anger, the Second Senator makes him a general for the battle. Aufidius closes the scene by commenting that if he and Marcius should meet on the battlefield, there is sure to be a fight to death.

Captain Donnithorne gives an acceptance speech and then toasts the Squire and Adam. In his toast to Adam, he announces that Adam will be working for the Squire, even though Adam has so far kept this information a secret because he has not yet had a chance to tell Mr. Burge, his employer. 0.text: This paper discusses the powers of the states and the federal government to impose taxes on the people. It discusses the notion of concurrent powers and exclusive powers as they relate to taxation. Concurrent powers are those that both the states and federal government share. Exclusive powers are those that only the states or the federal government can exercise. In the case of taxes, the authority of the federal government to levy taxes does not preclude the state governments from doing the same thing since taxation is a concurrent power. The only restriction on the authority of the state governments to levy taxes relates to duties on imports and exports. Congress can levy such taxes, but state governments can only do so with the consent of Congress. Hamilton acknowledges that the concurrent power of taxation could lead to situations in which state governments and the national government impose taxes on the same item, a situation that might be 'inexpedient.' However, Hamilton asserts that the prudence of governments can be relied on to avoid such situations. It is not necessarily a 'direct contradiction of power' for a state government and Congress to impose the same tax.

2.text: This study examines the powers of states and the federal government to impose taxes on citizens. It discusses the concept of concurrent powers and exclusive powers in the context of taxation. Concurrent powers are those that states and the federal government share. Exclusive powers are those that states or the federal government can exercise alone. In the case of taxes, the federal government's authority to levy taxes does not preclude state governments from doing the same, since taxation is a concurrent power. The only restriction on state governments' authority to levy taxes concerns tariffs on imports and exports. Congress can levy such taxes, but state governments can only do so with the consent of Congress. Hamilton recognizes that the concurrent power of taxation could lead to situations in which state governments and the national government impose taxes on the same item, a situation that could be 'inexpedient'. However, Hamilton asserts that the prudence of governments can be counted on to avoid such situations. It is not necessarily a 'direct contradiction of power' if a state government and Congress impose the same tax.

0.text: Mehevi and the other chiefs seem slightly angry at Tommo after Marnoo leaves. Even Kory-Kory appears to bear him a small grudge. Tommo now has been in the valley for about two months and his leg feels so well that he moves around easily. One day he makes a small 'pop-gun' out of bamboo for a six-year old boy, which shoots items out when one blows on it. The boy is fascinated. Soon after, groups of men and women appear and beg Tommo to make more. He does so, and they all run around like children playing with the guns. Their excitement continues for almost ten days. Tommo stops wearing the shoes that he brought from the ship and he ties them in his bundle near the roof. One day Marheyo suggests interest in them and Tommo gives them to him. Marheyo starts wearing the shoes on a strap around his chest, as a bizarre necklace. The Typees do not work very frequently, but one task with which most women assist is the making of the cloth, or 'tappa. Tappa making involves boiling branches from trees and stretching fibers. The process is described in full

2.text: Tommo and the other chiefs seem slightly annoyed towards Tommo after Marnoo's departure. Even Kory-Kory seems to harbor a small grudge. Tommo has now been in the valley for about two months and his leg feels so well that he moves easily. One day, he makes a small 'blowing tube' out of bamboo for a six-year-old boy, which makes objects come out when you blow on it. The child is fascinated. Not long after, groups of men and women appear and beg Tommo to make more. He does, and they all run around like children playing with toys. Their excitement lasts almost ten days. Tommo stops wearing the shoes he brought from the ship and attaches them to his bundle near the roof. One day, Marheyo takes an interest in them and Tommo gives them to him. Marheyo starts wearing them as a strange pendant around his chest, attached to a belt. The Typees do not work very frequently, but one task that most women attend is the weaving of fabric, or 'tappa'. The weaving of tappa involves boiling tree branches and stretching the fibers. The process is described in detail.

0.text: Emma mourns the departure of Leon. Gloom pervades her thoughts over the loss, and romanticism colors her vision, as she makes him into 'a taller, handsomer, a more delightful, and a vaguer Leon. ' With the passage of time, her passion dims, and 'the black days she had known at Tostes  again. ' She becomes unpredictable, given to strange whims. Charles' mother only makes things worse. In the midst of Emma's depression, Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy bachelor and landowner, calls on Charles when one of his servants needs urgent medical treatment. Boulanger sees Emma as she helps her husband and notices her sensuousness. Attracted to Emma, he wonders how to get rid of his present mistress.

0.text: Jude starts looking for a job in Christminster, and as soon as he is offered one , he accepts it. By night he studies sincerely. He spends his money on books, pens and paper even though he cannot afford a fire. When it is too cold, he sits up reading wrapped in a greatcoat, hat and woolen gloves. He persuades his aunt to send him the portrait of Sue and she does so, but reluctantly, and with a warning not to contact Sue. But Jude learns that Sue is working in an ecclesiastical goods shop and eventually discovers her there one day at work. He does not introduce himself to her. Later, she passes him by on the street. He notices her elegance and sophistication in contrast to his own rustic ways. He still does not speak to her and resolves not to think of her except as a relative.

But Jude learns that Sue works in an ecclesiastical goods shop and eventually runs into her one day while she is at work. He doesn't approach her. He still hasn't spoken to her and decides not to consider her anything other than a relative.

0.text: After the combats of the first day at Ashby, the crowds eagerly await the events of the next day. The excitement reaches a fever pitch when the Disinherited Knight is attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of another mysterious character, the Black Knight, who comes to his aid, Ivanhoe overcomes his challengers, emerging the victor once again. After the victory, the Black Knight disappears. Rowena crowns the Disinherited Knight, who is now forced to raise his visor and show his face. He is revealed to all as Ivanhoe, Cedrics son. Severely wounded, he faints at Rowenas feet.

0.text: As Fouquet accompanies D'Artagnan to see the King, a man shoves a piece of paper in his hand. While D'Artagnan is talking with the King, Fouquet reads the letter. In Gourville's handwriting, the letter informs Fouquet that a white horse is ready to bear him to safety. The Fouquet destroys the note. Fouquet goes in to see the King. The King asks after his health. Fouquet makes one last attempt to clear his name and defend himself. A little while into their conversation, it is clear Fouquet needs to go to bed. The King summons D'Artagnan to escort the man. Fouquet refuses, saying that a simple footman would do. Once Fouquet leaves, the King orders that D'Artagnan follow him. He asks D'Artagnan to arrest Fouquet, then orders a bunch of draconian measures like a special carriage to prevent notes being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan admits to the King that he tried to save Fouquet, but says that now he will execute his orders. D'Artagnan leaves the King. As he leaves, he sees a very cheerful Gourville heading to Fouquet's lodgings.

0.text: Determined to fight off her depression, Eustacia decides to go to a 'gipsying,' or dance, in East Egdon. Envious of the young people dancing, and later, surprised by Wildeve's presence there, she consents to dance with her former lover and enjoys it more than she can understand. Allowing Wildeve to walk part way home with her, she encounters Clym and Venn, though Wildeve leaves her before Clym can see him. Sure he has seen Wildeve with Eustacia, Venn hurries to the inn and learns from questioning Thomasin that it was her husband. Thereupon, Venn keeps watch on Clym's house and on several occasions frustrates Wildeve's loitering outside the house and trying to communicate with Eustacia. Venn also calls on Mrs. Yeobright, urging her to establish relations with both Clym and Thomasin for the good of all. She decides to forgive Clym and call on him. At the same time, Clym tells Eustacia he must do something to improve relations with his mother.

2.text: Determined to fight her depression, Eustacia decides to go to a 'gipsying' or dance, in East Egdon. By letting Wildeve walk a bit with her, she meets Clym and Venn, although he leaves before Clym sees him. Sure that he has seen Wildeve with Eustacia, Venn rushes to the inn and learns from Thomasin that it was her husband. At the same time, Clym tells Eustacia that he must do something to improve his relationship with his mother.

0.text: Ellen, distressed by Edgar's refusal to console Isabella, went to visit her at Wuthering Heights. She told Isabella and Heathcliff that Catherine would 'never be what she was' and that Heathcliff should not bother her anymore. Heathcliff asserted that he would not leave her to Edgar's lukewarm care, and that she loved him much more than her husband. He said that if he had been in Edgar's place he would never have interfered with Catherine's friendships, although he would kill the friend the moment Catherine no longer cared about him. Ellen urged Heathcliff to treat Isabella better, and he expressed his scorn and hatred for his wife. He said Isabella knew what he was when she married him: she had seen him hanging her pet dog. Isabella told Ellen that she hated Heathcliff, and he ordered her upstairs so he could talk to Ellen. Alone with her, he told her that if she did not arrange an interview for him with Catherine, he would force his way in armed, and she agreed to give Catherine a letter from him

She told Isabelle and Heathcliff that 'Catherine would never be what she was' and that they should stop tormenting her. Heathcliff declared that he would never let Catherine fall into the weak hands of Edgar and that he loved her much more than his wife. He said that he would never have attempted to interfere with their friendships if he had been in Edgar's place, even if it had meant killing his friend once he had escaped Catherine. Ellen encouraged Heathcliff to treat Isabelle better, and he showed her his contempt and hatred for his wife. He told her that she knew what he was like as a husband: she had seen how he had hanged his dog. Isabelle told Ellen that she detested Heathcliff, and he forced her to go upstairs so that he could speak to her alone. Alone with her, he told her not to arrange meetings between him and Catherine, that he would break her arms to have her, and she agreed to give him a letter for Catherine.

0.text: The group spends the night around a fire in the desolate ruins of the fort. They eat bear meat for dinner. Looking out at the lake, Heyward hears noises. Uncas explain that wolves are prowling nearby. Hawkeye is pondering the meaning of paradise when he hears another sound. Uncas goes to investigate, and the group hears a rifle shot. Chingachgook follows his son, and those left behind hear a splash of water and another rifle shot. Chingachgook and Uncas return calmly. When Heyward asks what happened, Uncas shows him the scalp of an Oneida. After discussing the plan for the next day, the group falls asleep
